This discovery application surveys the railway networks of Central America and Cuba as documented through digitized historical maps and photos from the AGSL's Americas collection. There is an emphasis on the proliferation of these networks throughout the first half of the 20th Century, a time when American multinational corporations constructed railways in the region for the purpose of resource extraction and exportation (usually to the United States). Bananas, cacao, sugarcane, and tobacco were among the many crops transported from the hinterland to ports. Many maps and photos reflect this narrative, though the more mundane aspects of the railways are also highlighted: people waiting at stations, tracks cutting through the landscape, vendors selling goods to train passengers through carriage windows. Together, they reflect the diversity of experiences with, and cartographic productions of, the railways in the region.
